title: Fleming v. Board of Commissioners
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Ernest Fleming, Respondent,
        v.
        Board of Commissioners for Florence County School District
          Three, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2009-UP-044
  Submitted January 2, 2009 â€“ Filed January
15, 2009Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chalmers C. Johnson, of Mount Pleasant, for Appellant.
        Charles J. Boykin and Karla M. Hawkins, both of Columbia, for Respondent.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Florence County School District Three (District) employed
  Ernest Fleming as a teacher and a basketball coach under two separate
  contracts.Â  When the District declined to renew Flemingâ€™s coaching contract,
  Fleming sought judicial review of the Districtâ€™s decision.Â  Fleming now appeals
  from the circuit courtâ€™s order dismissing his action against the District
  because Fleming was not aggrieved by the construction or administration of a
  school law and because Fleming lacked a constitutionally protected property
  interest in continuing to coach in the future.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule
220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities.Â  
As to the question whether Fleming had the right to
  pursue circuit court review of the board of trusteesâ€™ decision:Â  S.C. Code Â§
  59-19-510 (2004) (limiting review of decisions by boards of trustees to matters
  arising from â€œthe construction or administration of the school lawsâ€); Rule
  8(a)(2), SCRCP (requiring plaintiff to plead â€œfacts showing that the pleader is
entitled to reliefâ€).Â  
As to the question whether Fleming possessed a
  property interest in continuing to coach in the future:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  59-25-410 (2004) (establishing procedures to protect property interest in
  teaching contracts); Johnson v. Spartanburg County Sch. Dist. No. 7, 314
  S.C. 340, 343, 444 S.E.2d 501, 502 (1994) (finding section 59-25-410 created
  property interest in teaching contract but not in non-teaching contract); Lexington
    County Sch. Dist. One Bd. of Trustees v. Bost, 282 S.C. 32, 36, 316 S.E.2d
  677, 679 (1984) (holding even if a school policy creates a property interest in
  continued employment as a teacher, it â€œdoes not create an entitlement to the
  extracurricular duty of coachingâ€); Hamilton v. Bd. of Trustees of Oconee
    County Sch. Dist., 282 S.C. 519, 524, 319 S.E.2d 717, 721 (Ct. App. 1984)
  (finding property interest in employment may come from express or implied
  contracts or from a mutual understanding, and holding â€œabstract need or desireâ€
or â€œunilateral expectationâ€ insufficient to establish property interest).Â  
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS, PIEPER, and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.Â

title: Phillips v. Horry County
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Diane B.
      Phillips, Appellant,
				v.
				Horry County, Respondent.
				____________________
				Richard Kevin
          Phillips, Appellant,
				v.
				Horry County, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2009-UP-045
Submitted December 12, 2008 â€“ Filed
  January 15, 2009Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James P. Stevens, Jr., of Loris, for Appellants.
				Victoria T. Vaught, of Conway, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Dianne B. Phillips and Richard Kevin Phillips appeal
  the order of the trial court granting summary judgment to Horry County.Â  They assert the trial court erred in holding the federal courtâ€™s finding of probable
  cause in their 42 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1983 (2000) claim collaterally estopped them from
  claiming a lack of probable cause in their remanded state law claims for
  malicious prosecution, false imprisonment, and assault and battery.Â  
This
  action arises from the Phillipsâ€™ arrest by Horry County law enforcement officer
  Kevin Jordan for breach of peace.Â  The charge against Mrs. Phillips was later dismissed.Â 
  The charge against Mr. Phillips was also dismissed after he performed community
  service.Â  
The
  Phillips brought separate actions against Horry County and Officer Jordan for
  assault and battery, malicious prosecution, false imprisonment, and violation
  of the civil rights under color of state law pursuant to 42 U.S.C.A Â§ 1983.Â 
  The defendants removed the action to federal court on the basis of federal
  question jurisdiction.Â  The federal court granted the defendantsâ€™ summary
  judgment finding, among other issues, that the officers had probable cause to
  arrest the Phillips and did not use excessive force.Â  It declined to exercise
  supplemental jurisdiction of the remaining state law claims and remanded the
  case to the Court of Common Pleas for Horry County.Â  The circuit court held
  that because the issues of probable cause and reasonable force had already been
  fully and fairly litigated in federal court and the Phillips had presented no
  additional evidence, they were precluded from relitigating the issues.Â  It held
  summary judgment was appropriate as the determination of those issues
  foreclosed the Phillipsâ€™ claims for assault and battery, false imprisonment,
  and malicious prosecution.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
On
  appeal, the Phillips assert for the first time that the circuit court
  mistakenly applied the federal test required by Â§ 1983 for â€œarguable probable
  causeâ€ while our state law requires â€œprobable cause in fact.â€Â  As this argument
  was neither raised to nor ruled on by the circuit court, it is not properly
  before this court.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d
  731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge
  to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
In
  their reply brief, the Phillips argue the circuit court erred in granting
  summary judgment because it:

	(1)
  adopted the federal test or standard for granting summary judgment in the
  applicable state law claims, (2) applied a subjective test, instead of an
  objective test, to determine whether the arresting officer had probable cause
  to arrest, (3) ignored the South Carolina â€œminorityâ€ rule that probable cause
  is ordinarily a question of fact for the jury, (4) ignored the issue that the
  appellants were arrested in their home which requires a higher standard of
  probable cause, (5) ignored several genuine issues of material fact and
  apparently viewed the evidence in the light most favorable to the Respondents,
  and finally (6) ignored issues bearing on the credibility of the witness.Â  

From
  the record before the court, we cannot discern whether any of these issues were
  raised to or ruled upon by the circuit court.Â  See Wilder Corp. v.
    Wilke, 330 S.C. at 76, 497 S.E.2d at 733 (1998) (stating an issue cannot be
  raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled
  upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review); Enriquez v.
    S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 374 S.C. 165, 167, 648 S.E.2d 582, 583 (2007)
  (appellant has the burden to provide an adequate record for review);Â  Shealy
    v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 460, 535 S.E.2d 438, 444-45 (2000) (trial
  courtâ€™s general ruling insufficient to preserve specific issue for appellate
  review; where trial court does not explicitly rule on argument raised, and no
  Rule 59 motion filed, appellate court may not address the issue); Grant v.
    S.C. Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 355-56, 461 S.E.2d 388, 392 (1995)
  (finding that an inaccuracy in the trial courtâ€™s order must be raised to the
  trial court by way of a motion to alter or amend a judgment before the
  inaccuracy may be challenged on appeal).Â  Furthermore, many of these arguments
  were raised for the first time in the reply brief. Â See Continental
    Ins. Co. v. Shives, 328 S.C. 470, 474 n.2, 492 S.E.2d 808, 811 n.2 (Ct. App.
  1997) (stating an appellant may not use the reply brief to argue issues not
  raised in the initial brief).Â  Accordingly we find the Phillipsâ€™ arguments are
  not properly before this court.Â  As the Phillips have not presented this court
  with any preserved arguments challenging the circuit courtâ€™s ruling, we must
  affirm.Â  
AFFIRMED.[1]
ANDERSON,
  HUFF, and THOMAS, JJ. concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Terrance T. Alston appeals his convictions of second degree lynching, armed
  robbery, assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature, and possession of

    v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587
  S.E.2d 691, 693-694 (2003) (â€œIn order for an issue to be preserved for

  nature of the alleged error so it can be reasonably understood by the court.â€).

PER CURIAM:Â  Efrain Thomas appeals his conviction for
  murder and possession of a firearm during a violent crime and his sentence of
  thirty yearsâ€™ imprisonment, arguing the circuit court erred in permitting the
  State to impeach him at trial using a prior conviction for unlawful possession
  of a weapon, arguing the prejudice he suffered because of this testimony was
  unfair and outweighed any probative value.Â  We
  affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Ohler
    v. U.S., 529 U.S. 753, 755 (2000) (â€œGenerally, a party introducing evidence
  cannot complain on appeal that the evidence was erroneously admitted.â€); State
    v. Wannamaker, 346 S.C. 495, 499, 552 S.E.2d 284, 286 (2001) (holding a
  party must object contemporaneously to the admission of evidence to preserve
  that issue for appellate review); State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 199,
  498 S.E.2d 642, 647 (1998) (placing on appellant the burden of presenting a
  sufficient record to allow review); State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 268,
  460 S.E.2d 409, 410 (Ct. App. 1995) (requiring a ruling on a motion in limine to exclude evidence to be elicited from a witness must be obtained immediately
  prior to the witnessâ€™s testimony in order to preserve the ruling for appellate
review without a contemporaneous objection).Â Â

  CURIAM:Â  Lewis Lloyd appeals his convictions and sentences for second-degree
  arson and assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature, arguing the
  trial judge erred: (1) in admitting Lloydâ€™s custodial statement to a police
  officer, and (2) in refusing to admit evidence of a victimâ€™s prior
  convictions.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and
  the following authorities: State v.
    Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 642, 541
  S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001) (stating to properly preserve an evidentiary issue for
  review, the moving party must also make a contemporaneous objection when the
  evidence is introduced unless the judge rules on the issue immediately prior to
  the introduction of the evidence); State v. Day, 341 S.C. 410, 420, 535
  S.E.2d 431, 436 (2000) (â€œ[W]hether a specific instance of conduct by the
  [victim] is closely connected in point of time or occasion to the [incident] so
  as to be admissible is in the judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be disturbed on
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion resulting in prejudice to the accused.â€); State
    v. Brown, 321 S.C. 184, 187, 467 S.E.2d 922, 924 (1996) (holding no abuse
  of discretion occurred where the trial judge refused to admit the victimâ€™s
  twenty-three-year-old manslaughter conviction â€œ[b]ased on the remotenessâ€ in
  time to the incident).Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., SHORT and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. McKenzie

   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">

	font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR
  RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina, Respondent,
				v.
				Dwayne S. McKenzie Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Darlington County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge 
Unpublished Opinion No. 2009-UP-061
Heard January 6, 2009 â€“ Filed January
  27, 2009
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Robert
  M. Dudek, Deputy Chief Appellate Defender for Capital Appeals, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliot, Special Assistant Attorney
  General Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr., of Cheraw,
  for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM: In
  this appeal from a conviction for second degree criminal sexual conduct with a
  minor and for committing or attempting to commit a lewd act on a minor, McKenzie
  asserts the trial court erred in refusing to allow him to testify during a
  pretrial hearing on the suppression of blood evidence.Â  Although a defendant is
  entitled to testify at a suppression hearing, this issue is not preserved for
  our review.
We
  affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: State v.
  Smith, 337 S.C. 27, 32, 522 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1999) (stating because a
  ruling from a motion in limine is subject to change, the losing party must make
  a contemporaneous objection when the contested evidence is presented at trial
  for the issue to be preserved on appeal); State v. Greene, 330 S.C. 551,
  556, 499 S.E.2d 817, 820 (Ct. App. 1997) (noting contemporaneous objection
  requirement not met to properly preserve an error for appellate review which
  was raised at a suppression hearing); State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 268,
  460 S.E.2d 409, 410 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating, "[a] ruling on the pre-trial
  motion is preliminary, and is subject to change based on developments at trial.").
  Â While some preliminary determinations may be deemed final when no evidence is
  taken between the trial court's ruling on a motion in limine and the evidence's
  introduction, additional testimony was presented herein before introduction of
  the blood evidence. Â See, e.g., State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637,
  541 S.E.2d 837 (2001).Â  Moreover, although a cursory review might lend itself
  to a conclusion that the ruling may be final since no other evidence would
  arguably affect this issue, that cursory view is unfounded since the trial
  court specifically invited McKenzie to revisit the issue by presenting the
  testimony of Jay Ervin, his alleged counsel; thus, the court's invitation
  specifically indicates the lack of finality on this evidentiary issue.
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS,
  PIEPER, and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.

title: Retail Properties v. Horne Properties
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">

font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Retail
      Properties, Inc., Respondent,
				v.
				Horne
      Properties, Inc., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2009-UP-062
Heard January 6, 2009 â€“ Filed January 28,
  2009Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Louis H. Lang and Ian D. McVey, of Columbia for Appellant.
				James A. Blair, III, of Greenville for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Horne Properties, Inc. (Horne) appeals from a jury verdict finding
  Retail Properties, Inc. (RPI) entitled to damages of $132,813 for Horneâ€™s
  breach of its contract with RPI.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
This matter involves an admitted contract between RPI and Horne,
  wherein RPI agreed to represent Horne as a preferred grocery-anchored shopping
  center developer in certain South Carolina counties.Â  RPI sued Horne after
  Horne failed to pay RPI under the contract for site acquisition services
  rendered after Horne developed a Publix at the intersection of Broad River Road and Kennerly Street in Columbia.Â  
RPI is a company formed by Tim Metzler that specializes in tenant
  selection. Metzler had previously worked for a company which developed large
  shopping centers, such as Wal-Mart.Â  When Metzler left employment with that
  company, multiple clients, including Publix Super Markets, requested Metzler
  continue to represent them.Â  Metzler testified these chains would engage tenant
  representation firms to explain the nuances of the market, traffic patterns,
  and demographics and come up with a strategy for possible markets.Â  Metzler
  stated the tenant representation role is different from a broker, who
  represents the buyer or the seller in a transaction.Â  A tenant representation
  firm educates the tenant on where to go; they help create a plan, they create
  the submarkets, and they find opportunities.Â  
Publix engaged RPI to initiate the move of Publix stores into South Carolina.Â  As part of this representation, Publix asked RPI to interface with fifteen
  or twenty different developers over time.Â  Based on longstanding relationships
  with developers, Publix may request the tenant representation firm work with
  particular developers.Â  In 2000, Publix requested RPI expand its areas of
  responsibility into Columbia and five counties in the Upstate.Â Â Â  After driving
  around Columbia, Publixâ€™s real estate manager, Bob Burkett, and Metzler
  identified five market opportunities.Â  At that time one of those developers,
  Horne, was soliciting business from Publix.Â  Based on a relationship Burkett
  had with William Hanks, a real estate manager for Horne, Burkett asked that RPI
  work with Horne when an opportunity arose.Â  Once Metzler, Burkett and Hanks
  identified some specific intersections of interest, the president of Horne,
  Richard Pressley, joined them in looking at the Columbia and Upstate areas.Â 
  According to Metzler, this business relationship ultimately resulted in RPI and
  Horne entering into a Fee Schedule agreement on March 2, 2000.Â  

	The agreement between RPI and Horne provided as follows:

Retail Properties, Inc. and Horne Properties
Fee Schedule

	Retail Properties, Inc. (RPI) agrees to represent Horne Properties
  as a preferred grocery-anchored shopping center developer in the following South Carolina counties:
	
		
			
				Richland  
				Anderson
				Greenville
				Pickens
			
			
				Lexington
				Cherokee
				Spartanburg
				 
			
		
	
	Retail Propertiesâ€™ assignment is to assist Publix Super Markets in
  improving their market share in the above markets.Â  Whenever there is an
  opportunity for a developer to be involved in a shopping center, it will be
  presented to Horne Properties.Â  As consideration for being a preferred shopping
  center developer, Horne Properties agrees to the following compensation
  agreement for RPI.
	Site Acquisition
	For each property purchased, a fee of $3.00 per sq. ft. on Publix
  GLA to be paid to RPI by the Seller and/or the Buyer at closing.

The document
  originally submitted by RPI to Horne contained additional services RPI could
  offer to Horne in exchange for additional fees and commissions, including
  assisting Horne with any joint ventures, Publix leases, and additional tenant
  leases.Â  However, these optional services were not desired by Horne and, as a
  result, the parties struck through all of these other services.Â  The document
  also originally provided under the site acquisition that RPI be compensated â€œa
  fee of 5% to be paid by the Seller and/or Buyer at closing with a $75,000
  guaranteed minimum per single transaction and $100,000 guaranteed minimum per
  assemblage transaction,â€ but this language was modified to provide for the $3
  per square foot of gross leasable area compensation, an industry standard.Â  Thus,
  the compensation for site acquisition work â€œwent from a percentage to a flat
  fee.â€Â  Additionally, language under the site acquisition proposal providing
  Horne would â€œguarantee a minimum fee of 2% of the purchase price to be paid to
  RPIâ€ for the sale/purchase of shopping centers was struck through by the
  parties.Â Â Â  Pressleyâ€™s instructions to Metzler were â€œto go find dirtâ€ that
  Horne could own and Horne was going to â€œdevelop it from the ground up.â€Â  
Working under this agreement, Metzler testified RPIâ€™s task with regard to site selection was to
  identify submarkets, further identify intersections, to help in a site
  selection process and, once everyone was in agreement on the site selection for
  a possible Publix, to go find the next site.Â  As site selector, RPI was to
  present all available opportunities to Horne and if the opportunities could be
  developed, assist them in the process.Â  Once an agreement was reached on site
  selection, Horne was responsible for continuing on the path to erect a Publix.Â 
  According to Metzler, RPI was to be compensated under the agreement â€œif we
  complete a site acquisition and identify a site.â€Â  In order to complete the
  site acquisition, RPI would â€œfilter all the information,â€ â€œgo down to the
  intersection,â€ â€œdo the work on the submarket,â€ and if Publix agrees to locate
  at that site, RPI would provide introductions to all the property owners.Â 
  Metzler testified, â€œ[O]nce the initial meetings are completed we are out of the
  picture, and on to the next site.â€Â  To achieve the final site acquisition, the
  developer would contract for the property and build a shopping center.Â  As a
  site selector, RPI would not be involved in the development of the property.Â  
In regard to the property that is the center of this dispute,
  Metzler and Burkett narrowed their search down from a submarket in the area to
  the particular intersection of Broad River and Kennerly.Â  At this time, RPI was
  under its agreement with Horne. The northwest corner was listed by the
  company Edens & Avant.Â  Metzler began to contact the owners of property on
  the northeast corner and discovered another developer, Joe Gentry, had title to
  one small parcel and held options to purchase all the other properties
  necessary for development of that corner.Â  At the instruction of Publix and
  Horne, Metzler approached Gentry with the opportunity to sell the property to
  Horne at a profit, but Gentry declined because he wanted to develop the
  property for Publix himself.Â  Publix instructed RPI to get both sides of
  property under contract so that both developers could present packages to
  Publix.Â  RPI then provided its full packet of information and research on the
  area to both developers.Â  The packages were submitted to Burkett, and he chose
  to present the northeast corner that Gentry had under contract for
  consideration by Publix.Â  Metzler testified that in 2000, an opportunity
  existed for Horne on the northwest corner, but there was no opportunity at that
  time for Horne as to the northeast corner that Gentry had under his control.Â 
  Both of the packages were ultimately rejected by Publix.Â  
Publix has a written rule whereby no one is allowed to resubmit a
  property site for consideration for at least one year.Â Â  In the spring of 2001,
  Philip Greenwall with Publix began traveling with Metzler in South Carolina and
  reviewed the areas looked into previously by Burkett and Metzler.Â  While
  looking at the northwest corner of Broad River and Kennerly that had been
  submitted again by a different developer, Greenwall indicated he liked the
  northeast corner better.Â  Greenwall suggested RPI get Horne involved in the
  northeast corner, so Metzler contacted Hanks and Pressley, who then instructed
  RPI to go back to the northeast corner and contact the property owners.Â  By
  this time, Gentry had dropped his options on the northeast corner.Â  Metzler
  contacted all of the property owners, who directed him to Tom Efland, one of
  the owners who was also acting as a representative for the other property
  owners.Â  
At the instruction of Hanks and Pressley, Metzler made arrangements
  for a meeting with Horne and Efland.Â Â Â  Metzler, Hanks and Pressley met with
  Efland at his office on July 11, 2001 and discussed the site, terms and
  conditions, and the possibility of putting the northeast corner under contract
  with Horne.Â Â  After the meeting, Metzler was told his work was finished on that
  job, that Horne would handle the negotiations with the property owners, and
  that RPI would be compensated. Pressley and Hanks then instructed Metzler to
  move onto another site in the Upstate.Â  
Approximately two months later, Horne sent RPI a termination
  letter dated September 13, 2001, stating it had come to Horneâ€™s attention RPI
  was representing other developers in the seven counties listed in the agreement
  and, because of this conflict of interest, Horne was terminating their
  agreement.Â  Metzler testified, while Horne was free to terminate the agreement
  at any time, RPI made full disclosure to Horne that it worked with other
  developers, sending out periodic reports which included information regarding
  RPIâ€™s work with all the developers.Â  Horne entered into a contract with Efland
  for his piece of property on September 25, 2001.Â Â Â  Ultimately, of the several
  projects on which RPI worked, Horne closed on two properties after the
  termination letter, including the northeast corner of Broad River and
  Kennerly.Â  While Horne paid RPI for the other project, it refused to pay on the
  Broad River and Kennerly one.Â  RPI presented evidence the gross leasable square
  footage of the Publix Horne subsequently developed at this location was
  44,271.Â  
Pressley, testifying on behalf of Horne, maintained RPIâ€™s duties
  under the agreement were to negotiate land contracts and help their personnel
  produce market data and trade area statistics, including population, household
  income, income per capita, new housing starts, current housing and schools.Â 
  Pressley stated Horne terminated its agreement with RPI because (1) RPI was
  working in the same market with other grocers, thereby potentially jeopardizing
  a relationship with Publix, (2) RPI had â€œother competitive developer
  relationships,â€ and (3) RPI failed to pursue the land contracts to the degree
  Horne had originally hoped.Â Â  Pressley testified to the various meetings and
  negotiations Horne had with the different landowners in regard to the northeast
  corner property.Â Â  He did not recall any meeting with Efland where Metzler was
  present.Â  Contracts were negotiated on the various properties in question for a
  period of around eight months, starting in late September 2001.Â Â  Pressley
  testified, had RPI still been representing Horne during that time, Horne would
  have expected RPI to be involved with these negotiations and execution of the
  contracts.Â  A Publix grocery store was subsequently constructed on the property
  and opened in November or December 2003.Â  Pressley testified no payments were
  made to RPI at the closing on this property because â€œthere were none due.â€Â  
When asked where in the agreement between the parties it provided
  RPI was supposed to negotiate land options with the property owners, Pressley
  stated RPI was a brokerage company, and it was inherent in the term â€œrepresentâ€
  and under the paragraph entitled â€œSite Acquisition.â€Â Â  Pressley further
  admitted he struck through many of the services offered by RPI, including those
  relating to additional tenant lease, Publix lease, and joint venture
  arrangement, and that he changed the compensation under site acquisition to the
  $3 per square foot of Publix gross leasable area to be paid by the seller
  and/or buyer at closing.Â  When questioned on whether there was a specific list
  of tasks RPI was required to perform in order to earn a commission, Pressley
  again stated that it was â€œinherent in that document.â€Â  Pressley admitted,
  however, that RPI had no authority to bind Horne in contracts.Â  
Prior to submission of the case to the jury, counsel for Horne
  submitted four requests to charge in the area of commissions, arguing the
  contract in question was in the nature of a brokerage fee agreement.Â  Counsel
  stated, â€œ[a]lthough there is a flat fee suggested,â€ that flat fee depended on
  whether there was a land contract commission.Â Â  Specifically, Horne sought the
  following instructions be given to the jury:

	1.Â  A broker is entitled to his commissions, if during the
  continuance of his agency, he is the efficient or procuring cause of the sale.
	2.Â  A broker will be regarded as the procuring cause if his
  intervention is the foundation upon which the negotiations resulting in the
  sale is begun.
	3.Â  It is the emphatic rule in this state that the broker must not
  only show that his efforts were the procuring cause of the sale but must
  further show that his intervention was during the continuance of an agency to
  sell or to find a purchaser.
	4.Â  A broker is never entitled to a commission for unsuccessful
  efforts.Â  The risk of failure is wholly his.Â  The reward comes only with his
  success.Â  The broker may devote his time and labor, and expend his money with
  ever so much devotion to the interests of his employer, and yet if he fails, if
  without effecting an agreement or accomplishing a bargain, he abandons the
  effort, or his authority is fairly and in good faith terminated, he gains no
  right to commission.

The trial court declined to instruct the jury on these four
  charges finding, â€œwhether you call it a commission, whether you call it a fee .
  . . the bottom line is. . . whether or not [RPI] did what [it] was supposed to
  do under the terms of the contract,â€ it was a contract for services and not
  land acquisition, and it was not a procuring cause issue and thus it was
  unnecessary to bring in â€œprocuring cause or anything along those lines.â€Â  Â The
  jury returned a verdict for RPI in the amount of $132,813, and Horne moved for
  a new trial based on the courtâ€™s failure to give the requested instructions.Â Â Â 
  The trial court denied the motion, and this appeal followed.
ISSUES
1.Â 
  Did the trial court err in concluding the fee schedule between the parties was
  a contract for services for a flat fee because the fee schedule clearly called
  for payment of a commission if earned?
2.Â  Did the trial
  court err in failing to charge the jury the law as to procuring cause because
  the issue in the case was the entitlement of RPI to a commission?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  action for breach of contract seeking money damages is an action at law.Â  Eldeco,
    Inc. v. Charleston County Sch. Dist., 372 S.C. 470, 476, 642 S.E.2d 726,
  729 (2007).Â  In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried by a jury, the
  jurisdiction of the appellate court extends merely to the correction of errors
  of law.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85,
  221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
On
  appeal, Horne asserts the trial court erred in concluding the fee schedule
  agreement was a contract for services.Â  It argues that RPI is a real estate
  broker that was engaged by Horne to represent it in Horneâ€™s attempt to develop
  Publix grocery stores.Â  Horne points to the fact that RPI often referred to its
  compensation under the agreement as a commission, and argues the $3 per square
  foot of leased space language met the definition of commission and, as such,
  RPI could only earn a commission if it was the procuring cause of the
  transaction.Â  Accordingly, Horne contends the trial court erred in failing to
  charge the jury on the law that in order to earn a commission, one must be the
  efficient or procuring cause of the transaction.Â  We disagree.
The
  trial judge is required to charge only the current and correct law of South
  Carolina, and the law to be charged to the jury is determined by the evidence adduced
  at trial. Â Â State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 231, 589 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2003).Â 
  To warrant reversal for refusal to give a requested instruction, the refusal
  must have not only been erroneous, but also prejudicial.Â Â Â  McCourt ex rel. McCourt
    v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 306, 457 S.E.2d 603, 606 (1995).Â  Refusal to
  give a properly requested charge is not error if the general instructions are
  sufficiently broad to enable the jury to understand the law and the issues
  involved.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â  
In
  arguing its position, Horne relies heavily on the case of Webb v. First Fed.
    Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n, 300 S.C. 507, 388 S.E.2d 823, overruled in part on other grounds by Myrtle Beach Hosp., Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach,
  341 S.C. 1, 532 S.E.2d at 868 (2000).Â  There, Webb, a real estate broker,
  attempted to broker a real estate deal for First Federal to sell certain
  property to Burger King for $155,000, and an agreement was reached with First
  Federal that Webb would receive a $15,000 commission.Â  The offer was made to
  Burger King, but Burger King declined.Â  Id. at 509, 388 S.E.2d at 824.Â 
  Sometime thereafter, Burger King asked Webb to contact First Federal about the
  lot, and when Webb did, he was told it was not available.Â  Approximately six
  months later, Burger King again asked Webb to approach First Federal about the
  availability of the lot.Â  First Federal indicated it had decided to do nothing
  with the property.Â  However, two months later, First Federal began negotiating
  with a franchisee of Burger King.Â  Three months after that, a subsidiary of
  First Federal leased the property to the franchisee, and a Burger King was
  subsequently erected there.Â  Id. at 509, 388 S.E.2d at 825.Â  When Webb
  noticed construction of the restaurant, he brought an action against First
  Federal alleging he was entitled to compensation based upon quantum meruit and
  implied contract.Â  Id. at 508, 509, 388 S.E.2d at 824, 825.Â  Reciting
  the same law Horne sought to be instructed to the jury in requests number three
  and four regarding entitlement to commissions and procuring cause, this court
  noted the unappealed ruling in the matter that the actual contract between Webb
  and First Federal had ended when Burger King refused the initial offer, and
  determined the facts of the case did not support a contract implied in law.Â  Id. at 512-13, 388 S.E.2d at 826.
We
  find the Webb case to be clearly distinguishable.Â  In the case at hand,
  RPI sought recovery for breach of the partiesâ€™ written contract, not under the
  theory of an implied contract.Â  Further, the evidence adduced at trial shows
  RPI was not acting simply as a real estate broker attempting to secure a deal
  between parties for the sale of land.Â  Rather, as testified to by Metzler, RPI acted as a tenant
  representative, whose role is different from a broker who represents the buyer
  or the seller in a transaction.Â  Metzler testified RPIâ€™s task with regard to its site selection
  duties for Horne was to identify submarkets, further identify intersections,
  help in a site selection process and, once everyone was in agreement on the
  site selection for a possible Publix, to go find the next site.Â  According to
  Metzler, RPI fulfilled these duties with respect to the Broad River and
  Kennerly location, and was instructed by Horne to move onto the next site.Â 
  Although Pressley disagreed that RPI fulfilled its duties as to this site,
  Horne presented no evidence that RPI was not engaged to perform those tasks to
  which Metzler testified, and whether Metzler fulfilled those duties under the
  contract was a question for the jury.Â  Under the agreement between the parties,
  Horne Properties agreed to compensate RPI for performing site acquisition on
  each property purchased, the fee being determined based on the square footage
  of the Publix thereafter erected.Â  While it is obvious the fee due could not be
  computed unless and until a Publix was actually erected on the location in
  question, neither this fact, nor the fact that the parties may have referred to
  the expected compensation as a commission establishes that RPI was acting
  merely as a broker, nor was there any evidence of record that RPI acted merely
  as a broker.Â  Further, the trial court instructed the jury on basic contract
  law, including that in order for the contract to be binding and enforceable,
  the parties must have intended to enter a contract and, through their
  negotiations, they must have reached a mutual understanding of the terms of the
  contract.Â  
We agree with the trial court that the evidence submitted at trial
  shows the contract between the parties was not simply one for land acquisition
  entitling RPI to only a brokerage fee, but was a contract for services, with a
  flat fee to be determined upon the successful completion of a Publix on the
  site upon which RPI performed those services.Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial
  court properly declined to charge the
  jury on the law relating to commissions and procuring cause as requested by
  Horne.Â  See Miller v. Schmid Labs., Inc., 307 S.C. 140, 142-43,
  414 S.E.2d 126, 127 (1992) (noting instruction by the trial court of irrelevant
  and inapplicable principles of law was clearly erroneous and may have served to
  confuse the jury, and holding it is reversible error to charge a correct
  principle of law as governing a case when such principle is inapplicable to the
  issues on trial).Â  See also Cole v. Raut, 378 S.C. 398,
  404, 663 S.E.2d 30, 33 (2008) (noting a jury charge consisting of irrelevant
  and inapplicable principles may confuse the jury and will constitute reversible
  error if the juryâ€™s confusion affects the outcome of the trial).Â  Further, assuming, as Horne contends, there is
  evidence that work performed by RPI fell within the definition of a real estate
  broker, the issue of the partiesâ€™ obligations under the contract was a question
  for the jury.Â  Thus, we find the general
  instructions given by the trial court were sufficiently broad to enable the
  jury to understand the law and the issues involved such that failure to give
  the requested charges was not error. 
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, the judgment below is
AFFIRMED. 
HUFF,
  THOMAS, and LOCKEMY, JJ., concur.
